subsection.title: Polar Ice
subsection.p:
Three main factors influence the energy balance of the Earth and its temperature:
The total energy influx from the sun
The chemical composition of the atmosphere
The ability of the Earth's surface to reflect light, or albedo

Because polar ice reflects light from the sun, the radiation balance over an ice-covered ocean is very different from the balance over an open ocean. Sea ice also influences deep-ocean circulation, and small changes in ocean currents can have a large effect on coastal and global climate. Thus, the ice component of the climate system, called the cryosphere, plays an important role in the Earth's radiation balance.

General circulation models predict that global warming over the next few decades will occur mainly in the polar regions. As polar ice begins to melt, less sunlight is reflected into space, which raises the overall temperature and fuels further melting. This process is called ice albedo feedback.

Since satellite monitoring began in 1979, Arctic sea ice cover has decreased about 10% per decade, falling to a startling new low in 2007. NASA scientists are working to understand this sudden decline and what it means for climate change. "It really is imperative that we try to understand the interactions between the ice, ocean and atmosphere," according to senior scientist Josefi no Comiso.

Numerous factors influence the freezing point of sea water, including its salinity, or mineral content. Unlike tropical oceans, which are temperature-stratified (water near the surface is warmer), the Arctic Ocean is salinity-stratified. In this Lesson we'll develop a formula for the freezing temperature of water in terms of its salinity.

subsection.title: Coordinate Formula for Slope
subsection.p: Slope measures the change in one variable with respect to unit changes in another.To calculate the net change between two points on a number line, we can subtract their coordinates. \blert{\text{net change} = \text{final value} - \text{starting value}}

For example, if you walk from 3^\text{rd} street to 8^\text{th} street, your distance, s, from the center of town has increased by 5 blocks, or \Delta s = 8 - 3 = 5 If the temperature T drops from 28\degree to 22\degree, it has decreased by 6\degree, or \Delta T = 22-28 = -6

assemblage.p: The net change is positive if the variable increases, and negative if it decreases.

sidebyside.p: Thus, for the graph shown at right, the net change in t-coordinate from P to Q is \Delta t = 51 - (-23) = 74 We can use the notion of net change to calculate slopes. Recall the coordinate formula for computing slope.

statement.p: In the coordinate formula for slope, why do we require that x_1 \ne x_2?

solution.p: The denominator of a fraction cannot be zero.

subsection.p: Notice that the numerator of the slope formula, y_2 - y_1, gives the net change in y, and the denominator, x_2 - x_1, gives the net change in x. The coordinate formula is equivalent to our definition of slope, m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} , and is useful for computing slope when we know the coordinates of two points on a line.

li.p:

m=\frac{\Delta W}{\Delta t}=\frac{W_2-W_1}{t_2 - t_1}
between these two points. Think of moving from P to Q in two steps, first moving horizontally to the right from P to the point R, and then vertically from R to Q. The coordinates of R are (13, 188.6). (Do you see why?) Then
\Delta t \amp= t_2-t_1 = 13-3=10 \Delta W \amp= W_2-W_1= 258.3-188.6=69.7
and thus
m=\frac{W_2-W_1}{t_2-t_1}=\frac{258.3 - 188.6}{13 - 3}=6.97

subsection.title: Point-Slope Formula
subsection.p: Now consider using the slope formula for a different problem. If we know the slope of a line and the coordinates of one point on the line, we can use the coordinate formula for slope to find the y-coordinate of any other point on the line. Instead of evaluating the formula to find m, we substitute the values we know for m and (x_1, y_1). Then we plug in the x-coordinate of the unknown point and solve for y.

statement.p: A line has slope \dfrac{-3}{4} and passes through the point (1,-4) . Which equation can you use to find the y-coordinate of the point on the line with the x-coordinate of 6?

subsection.p: There is only one line that passes through a given point and has a given slope. So, if we know the slope of a particular line and one point on the line, we can find its equation. Remember that the equation is really just a formula that gives the y-coordinate of any point on the line in terms of its x-coordinate. To find the equation, we can use the coordinate formula for slope.

li.p: Graph the line that passes through the point (1, -4) and has \text{slope}=\dfrac{-3}{4} .
Find an equation for the line in part (a).

sidebyside.p: We first plot the given point, (1,-4), and then use the slope to find another point on the line. The slope is m=\dfrac{-3}{4}=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} , so starting from (1,-4) we move down 3 units and then 4 units to the right. This brings us to the point (5,-7). We draw the line through these two points.

assemblage.title: Point-Slope Form
assemblage.p:
The equation of the line that passes through the point (x_1, y_1) and has slope m is y = y_1 + m(x-x_1) You may also see the formula written in an alternate version:
y - y_1 = m(x-x_1)\qquad\text{ or }\qquad \frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1}=m

subsection.title: Finding a Linear Model
subsection.p: If we have two data points for a linear model, we can find its equation. We use two steps: first we compute the slope of the line, then we use the point-slope formula.

statement.p:
It cost a bicycle company $9000 to make 50 touring bikes in its first month of operation and $15,000 to make 125 bikes during its second month.
Find a linear equation for the company's monthly production cost, C, in terms of the number of bikes made, x.
State the slope and vertical intercept of your line, including units. What do they tell you about the problem?

li.p: We first find two data points, (x, C), from the information given.

Step 1: Compute the slope of the line.
m=\frac{C_2-C_1}{x_2-x_1}= \frac{15,000-9000}{125-5} = 80

Step 2: Apply the point-sope formula, using (50,9000) for (x_1,y_1)
C\amp=C_1 +m(x-x_1)
\amp=9000 +80(x-50)
\amp=9000 +80x-4000
The equation is C=5000+80x

The slope is 80 dollars per bike, and it tells us the cost of producing each bike. The vertical intercept is 5000, and it tells us that the bicycle company's fixed costs (before production begins) are $5000.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p: In this section, we studied three different formulas associated with linear equations: the slope-intercept formula, the coordinate formula for slope, and the point-slope formula. How are these formulas related, and how are they different?

li.p:
What is the difference between the slope formula
m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}
and the point-slope formula
m= \frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} ?
They are really the same formula, but they are used for different purposes:
The slope formula is used to calculate the slope when we know two points. We know (x_1, y_1) and (x_2, y_2), and we are looking for m.
The point-slope formula is used to find the equation of a line. We know (x_1, y_1) and m, and we are looking for y = mx + b.
